ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Knowledge: 
Understanding of why LATAM lags behind in development and the three pitfalls (acute inequality and extreme poverty; weak rule of law and high citizen insecurity; low productivity and GDP/capita growth) that hold the region back; Economic history of LATAM including the colonial period, Import Substitution, the Lost Decade, periods of Populism, and current day challenges

Insight:
The drug issue must be treated as a public health issue. Do not marry yourself to any policy, even the good ones; as the times change, so do the needs

I had the opportunity to delve deeply into one specific country's economic history and context through the final essay, which I appreciated. I deepened my overall understanding of broader economic trends in the LAC region.

I developed my abilities to read, analyze, and write about topics related to Latin American economics. As all students are required to give 20 minute presentations to the class, I improved my presentation-making and giving skills.
How to read papers regarding economic development
I now have a general overview of Latin American economic history and am aware of the three pre-development traps that challenge the region.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
This class teaches you to think like an economist in the real world and to evaluate the tradeoffs of policy

Weaknesses:
The weekly presentations lasted too long sometimes. I wish there were more time to hear Professor Zedillo talk from his experience or open the floor to questions.

The course provides a good broad overview of the major economic trends in Latin America in the past century. It also enables you to delve deeply into one economic topic or country in the region. The course is strengthened by Prof. Zedillo's unique vision, and the best parts of the lecture are when the Professor provides his specific insight onto topics that overlap with his work experience and history as President. 

With that said, class engagement was overall poor, which I believe is a direct result of the environment created by the lecturer. Rather than asking the classroom questions and letting students discuss amongst themselves/share their own views, the interaction is very one-directional despite this being a seminar course. It was disappointing to spend so much of class time reviewing the readings through the student presentations, rather than delving into the material more deeply. The schedule for student presentations was also poorly managedsome students had to present twice and some only once, with no prior warning that this would be the case. It would have also been nice to receive more clear instructions about the final papers expectations further in advance. 

Content-wise, I believe the course is most enjoyable when the incoming student already has a good working knowledge of Latin American economic history and is looking to refresh or deepen that knowledge. I wish we had spent more time discussing some of the crises in the 1990s and early 2000s, which we somewhat glossed over. 

I also wish I would have received specific feedback on my midterm exam, as I have no idea what I could have improved on or whether I was factually incorrect or not.

it was a really interesting class and i learned a lot, but the learning curve in the beginning was very high i had to teach myself a lot of stuff about foreign exchange rates. the whole first half of the class is mostly about foreign exchange rates. it would have been helpful to have some of those basics explained more in class.
I think the workload was too much, and no feedback was given on any assignment other than the midterm. I also think that office hours should be held.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It depends. The readings in this class are very challenging. If you are deeply interested in Latin America and economic development, this is a good class to take, but know it will be hard.

I would only recommend the course if the student already has some working knowledge of Latin American economic history and is looking to somewhat deepen or refresh that knowledge, or delve deeply into one specific case study through the final exam.

I would highly recommend this course to other students. Taking a class with Professor Zedillo is an incredible opportunity that anyone remotely interested in economics should take. His knowledge of globalization and Latin American economics is so deep, much of it coming from his experience being the president of Mexico right after NAFTA was signed and implemented.

its a good course, but a ton of work especially in the beginning of the class. it really depends on if youre basically willing to teach yourself the material, but its there for you and mostly interesting
I would recommend the course to a student with significant expertise on Latin American history, politics, and economics. I dont think a student unfamiliar with Latin America should take this course.
